item.title: Welcome to ENG 313 Portfolio

item.content:encoded: This website is the portfolio for Technical Writing course portfolio (

item.title: Résumé and Cover Letter
item.dc:creator: kwangju94
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_79" align="alignnone" width="2304"] Image source: https://211sepa.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/career-fair.jpg[/caption]

So You Want to Get a Job...

Hey there, you are the college student who are seeking a job or an internship. You have a degree (or not yet). You have skills. You have knowledge which you had learnt during college year. You have a leadership experience in your student organization or fraternity. You have a volunteer experience. You think you have enough qualification to get a job. You successfully contact the company and HR people require you to prove whether you have a qualification or not. Do they know your qualification? Not necessarily (unless they have contacted you in advance). It's your job to prove your qualification! But, how?

Why this is important

Here comes why the way to prove your qualification is VITAL for your job seeking. Generally, we send several documents to the employers to determine whether oneself is qualified or not for this work. There are two main documents you can show HR people. One is called a résumé, , and the other is called a cover letter.

How to Write a Great Résumé

It is also important that you write a resume in an appropriate way. Remember, even when you write a job letter you have to use a rhetoric. "Why? It's just a job letter not a literature or something!" Nah... I mean the way you use a rhetoric is quite different. Here, you are 'persuading' the potential employers that "I am qualified for this job so you may want to hire me." Therefore, you may want to write your documents in a persuasive way. In order to do so, here are some guidelines you may want to follow.
  1. Know who/what they want. Go to the job description site and remember who they want to hire, what is their desirable skills.
  2. Know what you know. You have this, you have that, and so on. You want to show something matching with the job description you have found at 1.
  3. Write your document in a persuasive manner including all your skills and qualifications and try to match both.

My Job Documents

In this technical writing class, I made a 'job packet' including my resume and cover letter. Here's how I wrote those documents.

Job Description (I haven't wrote this though)

[caption id="attachment_80" align="alignnone" width="1920"] Job descriptions of CoverMyMeds. They want a co-op developer. (From http://cmm.applytojob.com/apply/wSEiMV/Software-Coop-Engineer)[/caption] The company I found was called CoverMyMeds, located in Columbus, Ohio. According to the job description, they are looking for developers handling health care system. The Co-op engineers will work for 6 months. They will use Ruby On Rails, PHP, Python, PostgreSQL, Git, and so on. They described what co-op engineers will do, as well as what they expect for co-op engineers. You may want to look for more descriptions at the link provided.

Cover Letter

[caption id="attachment_77" align="alignnone" width="884"] My Cover Letter to HR people there[/caption] It's important to know, according to my technical writing professor, the following things when you are writing a cover letter.
  1. Name of the company (REALLY IMPORTANT; if you misspell the company name they won't want you)
  2. Job title (REALLY IMPORTANT; you know what you are applying for)
  3. Name and title of contact person (If you know this they will like more)
  4. Description of the position you are applying (We have done this already)
  5. Additional information
I followed the ordinary form of the cover letter which was sent to the employer of CoverMyMeds. First of all, I mentioned my name, address, phone number, and e-mail so that the people there could reply me back. Secondly I mentioned the name of the employer whom I met at the last fall career fair. At the body part of the cover letter I tried as much as I can persuade the employer that I fit this job. I listed several experience which related the job description above. For example, I discussed what I had done as a technical manager during a web application development project, as well as skills I learned such as PostgreSQL and Python. I showed what I have done as a TA showing my leadership and problem solving skills. To impress the employers, I used 'action verbs,' which raised the 'credibility' and 'liveliness' of my qualification. I ended my cover letter in an ethical manner; polite closing statement such as 'I look forward to discussing this opportunity' and 'I appreciate your time and consideration.'

Resume

[caption id="attachment_78" align="alignnone" width="1524"] Resume[/caption] So here I wrote my resume. My resume is compact, restricted to a single page, having all the qualifications in an appropriate manner. At the beginning I put my name and contact information so that the employers can reply. I had clearly mentioned my objectives - why I am writing this resume and for what purpose. According to my professor, the employer may not know for what purpose this resume was written if he/she can't see an objective part. In the 'education' part I clearly mentioned my school name, degree pursuing, major and minor, organization involvement, and graduation date. I included my overall GPA since it is above 3.0, showing I have a good academic standing. Other sections, work experience, projects, and skills, are just a summary of what I had written in the cover letter. The difference between my cover letter and resume is quite simple but important. All the descriptions in my resume is compact as possible, summarizing to few bullet points, emphasizing the important parts only so that the employers can easily figure out the qualifications from the resume. However, the cover letter has full descriptions of what I have done, what skills and qualifications I have, and why I am qualified for this job.

item.title: Short Recommendation
item.dc:creator: kwangju94
item.content:encoded:
You may read the entire document here. I got a chance to write a recommendation letter to Miami IT department about the problem of on-campus Wi-Fi services. Recently, MU-WIRELESS, Miami's on-campus wireless network service, has interrupted many times. This raised several complaints from students. Therefore, I had investigated the researched the possible solutions Miami University could take to improve its Wi-Fi service.

'Introduction' Part

[caption id="attachment_102" align="alignnone" width="1268"] Part of 'Introduction'[/caption] The 'Introduction' part explains the agenda (subject and purpose) of this recommendation paper, "how Miami University can improve its Wi-Fi service." I mentioned the background reason I was pursuing such an investigation. In order to raise the credibility, I distributed the survey to my classmates asking their experience of MU-WIRELESS. [caption id="attachment_114" align="alignnone" width="1264"] Brief summary of the result[/caption] [caption id="attachment_115" align="alignnone" width="1264"] How this letter is organized[/caption] The organization of the letter and brief summary of the result and recommendations are also included in the introduction part.

'Method' Part

The method part was mainly concentrated on how I investigated this issue. It was important to hear the students' opinion about MU-WIRELESS service since they are the main users of this service. I had generated the questionnaire and distributed to my classmates. Several questions asked to the students were:
  1. To what extent are you satisfied with Wi-Fi experience overall in Miami?
  2. What do you think is the strength of MU-WIRELESS service?
  3. What do you think is the weakness of MU-WIRELESS service?
  4. What would you suggest so that Miami can improve MU-WIRELESS service?
The rhetorical strategy I used here was special. Questions were not only to ask them what the problem is, but also to let them know their problem and propose the possible solutions. There were several positive responds about Wi-Fi service, such as "free service", "everywhere", and "convenient". However, there were more negative opinions like "cuts off many times", "slow", "traffic problem", or "weak connection". Students also wrote their own recommendations how Miami could have done better to its on-campus Wi-Fi service. Several recommendations raised were:
  • "Make dorms have more internet connection capacity so it works faster. Also make sure it doesn't disconnect between buildings"
  • "more routers to improve connections and getting the fastest internet possible"
  • "Add better routers to buildings with weak signals, offer more wired connections in places such as the libraries."
  • "May set more port out of the building"

Discussion of 'Alternative Solutions'

[caption id="attachment_120" align="alignnone" width="1252"] Possible Solutions Found![/caption] Based on the survey results and further investigation, I got 4 possible solutions to be proposed to Miami IT Department. I got an assistance from my 'Computer Networking' course materials I had done last semester. I had also found the benefits and side effects after we choose a particular option, as well as the cost in US dollars Miami has to spend in order to solve the problem. [caption id="attachment_119" align="alignnone" width="548"] Further investigation of each solution; including advantages and disadvantages, as well as the cost[/caption] The investigation and analysis are strictly focused on the interest of IT Department. If the result doesn't make sense to them, they won't read this recommendation anymore. It is the writer's - myself - duty to understand their interest and situation and reflect to the writing. All the advantages and side effects mentioned above are possible scenarios technicians of IT department can encounter any time. Expected costs were determined based on following search results. I have found prices for several routers, as well as costs to establish new server.
  • Routers
  • Server 1
  • Server 2
When discussing the possible solutions, the rhetoric was to be unbiased so that the audience (IT Dept.) can determine their choice in an objective manner.

'Conclusion' and 'Recommendation' Parts

[caption id="attachment_117" align="alignnone" width="552"] 'Priority' of the solutions; meaning which one is more reliable solution[/caption] [caption id="attachment_126" align="alignnone" width="556"] Conclusion[/caption] It's time to propose my own recommendation among 4 possible solutions. Unlike the previous section, it couldn't be unbiased and had to include my own opinion. Still, the recommendation part was written after thorough analysis of advantages, disadvantages, and costs mentioned in the sections above. I prioritized all the solutions in an ascending order, where 1 means the best solution. At last, I wrote a persuasive explanation of why I had chosen a particular solution as my recommendation. As always, I had to consider IT technicians' (who are going to read the recommendation letter) interest.

item.title: Long Report
item.dc:creator: kwangju94
item.content:encoded:
You may read the entire document here. This work was done with Gage Laugenberg and Billy Gallo.

Miami Dining Service has a problem...

It was the fall 2015, when I became a junior in the college and had to live off-campus. At the same time, I lost my privilege - all the food options will be given with a discount - over on-campus dining service. The problem rises when I noticed the dramatic deduction of the meal plan. I had to recharge my meal plan twice this semester, whereas I didn't have to do so when I lived on-campus (meaning living in the residence hall). Furthermore, I also found we don't necessarily have to eat on campus since the price and quality of uptown restaurants now give us the better option than eating on-campus. I believed this may be harmful to the competitive of on-campus dining service. Therefore, Gage Laufenberg, Billy Gallo, and I had decided to investigate this issue and find the possible solutions.

Method

The investigation method was on three main tracks.
  • Survey. We asked students, either living on- or off-campus, about their dining habits and satisfaction rate. We distributed the results based on their demographics (academic year, on-/off-campus, etc.). We also gathered their preferences of on-campus cafeteria and to what extent they like it. Lastly, students also had to respond their opinions about uptown restaurants and comparison to on-campus dining services.
  • Field research. We visited uptown restaurants and on-campus cafeteria, had a meal, and compared two, in terms of price and food quality.
  • Investigating other colleges' dining option. We had researched other colleges such as UCLA. (Referring to  Business Insider and USA TODAY)

Project Proposal

Before starting our research, we had to provide the appropriate information of the way we pursued this research. We clarified the problem  we had encountered and background information. We had used the logical rhetoric to provoke the readers' sympathy. The proposed audience would be the members of Miami community so it was important to make them understand our situation. Then we discussed our goals and plans.

Progress Report

The progress report discussed the following agendas.
  1. Past work we had done before this progress report was released.
  2. Current phase. This part is for the current research progress at the time this progress report was released.
  3. Future plan. We discussed what we would do after this progress report was released.
  4. Any problem we had encountered. We mentioned our time and budget limitation in a persuasive manner.
We included a Gantt chart to show our research progress and future plan effectively.

Final Report

Our final report consists of the executive results, conclusions, and recommendations to Miami Dining Service team. This report was also written for other Miami students who are interested in improving Miami Dining Services. We clearly mentioned our research criteria and methods in advance, in order to make sure the readers know what this report is talking about. At the result part, Excel charts were included for easier understanding of the result. The conclusion part was mostly the summary of the whole final report with unbiased manner, where the recommendation is thoroughly based on our viewpoints.

item.title: Monte Carlo Investigation
item.dc:creator: kwangju94
item.content:encoded:
You may read the entire document here.

Purpose of this project

This project was from 'Math and Computer Science' class (CSE 270M), led by Professor Norm Krumpe (krumpenj@miamioh.edu). The purpose of this project is to ensure my understanding of Monte Carlo simulation and extend it in an appropriate and creative way.

'Personal Statement'

Following is the personal statement I have submitted to my professor, about this project.
Monty Hall game is the game from the famous American TV show <Let's Make A Deal>. There are 3 rooms, one with ferrari, and the others with a goat. Each player can choose one room so that he/she gets either Ferrari or a goat. When he/she choose one room, the MC will open the door of the room which doesn't have a Ferrari. Then the player has a chance to change. It's his/her rights to change or not. Typically, it is known that changing the choice is more profitable than not changing. The probability to win the game is 67% if the player changes, and 33% if the player doesn't change. Now, I'm expanding this problem to two situations. 1. What if there are 4 or 5 rooms? Each player will have a single or 2 chances to change his/her choice. How will the probability be affected in this case? Will it be changed, or will it be same as 3 doors with a single change to change the first choice? (Moreover, will it depends on whether the total number of rooms are odd or even? How many times should the player be offered to change his/her choice in order to win? What if there are 2 Ferrari cars?) 2. What if the MC is offensive to the player. The number of rooms will be stricted to 3. In this case, the MC will decide whether he/she will open one of the rooms or not. The player cannot predict whether the MC will open the room or not. The MC also can decide whether the player can change his/her choice or not. In short, it is TOTALLY RANDOM. Will it affect the probability? (This is something redundant, but I found one article about the relation between the Monty Hall game and Pi(3.141592...). I'm also researching this if the time allows.)
 
What Experience? Professor Norm had talked about the Monty Hall game in this class. After that, I actually simulated the Monty Hall game using Monte Carlo simulation. And then, I found some interesting articles (written in Korean language) which extends the monty hall game.
 

Research Method

I have used Java programming language to pursue all the simulations. All the codes were thoroughly tested and results were logged. You may want to read Java code here.

Documentation Specification

The documentation of this project mainly consists of the executive summary and computations. I briefly mentioned the reason I was doing this research as well as background information so that the readers understand this research. Then, I had shown my calculation with the result of simulation and short discussion of it.

Reference

  • http://www.cut-the-knot.org/hall.shtmlhttp://math.stackexchange.com/questions/608957/monty-hall-problem-extended
  • https://course.ie.cuhk.edu.hk/~engg2430a/ENGG2430A/5b36d3f2-f3db-4417-a752-c4f7e385a7c6.htm
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8KnMlG6Td-o
  • http://mathworld.wolfram.com/MontyHallProblem.html
  • http://carma.newcastle.edu.au/jon/Preprints/Books/EMA/Exercises/For%20others/rg-Monty%20Hall.pdf

item.content:encoded: (If you want to read the papers directly, select any menu above) My name is Kwangju Kim, studying computer science at Miami University. This website contains all the projects I had pursued during my 'Technical Writing' class. Technical writing skills are really important no matter where I work, so I believe this portfolio is helpful in showcasing mine.
